coredata.dc:title: Oxygen vacancies in actiniae-like Nb2O5/Nb2C MXene heterojunction boosting visible light photocatalytic NO removal

coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic oxidation is a green and energy-saving technology for removing the low concentration NO in ambient atmosphere. High efficient and stable photocatalysts are essential for achieving excellent NO conversion effect. In this work, oxygen vacancy-rich Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction photocatalysts were prepared from Nb2C MXene by hydrothermal process and heat treatment in H2/Ar. The (001) facet-dominant Nb2O5 nanorods in-situ grown on Nb2C MXene formed an actiniae-like structure, which promotes the active site exposure and enlarges the reaction interface. Under visible light, the optimized photocatalyst exhibits excellent NO removal rates in the relative humidity range of 25–75%. Mechanism research shows that the oxygen vacancies greatly improve the photocatalytic NO oxidation capacity. Oxygen vacancies on (001) facet of Nb2O5 nanorods can boost the visible light absorption, effectively adsorb and activate the reactant gas. The separation of photogenerated carriers was synergistically enhanced by the oxygen vacancies and Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic illustration for the preparation process of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C.

(a, b) SEM images (the inset is natural actiniae), (c) TEM and (d) HRTEM images of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. (e) XRD patterns of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, Nb2C MXene and TT-Nb2O5. (f) EPR spectra of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C tested at room temperature.
High-resolution XPS spectra of (a) Nb 3d, (b) C 1s and (c) O 1s of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2C.
Elemental mapping images of (a) pristine Nb2C and (b) Nb2C-OH after defluorination (scale bar 25 µm). (c) XRD patterns of Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2C-OH derived Nb2O5/Nb2C.

(a) UV–vis diffuse reflection absorption spectra and (b) plots of (αhν)1/2 vs photon energy of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, and Nb2O5/Nb2C. (c) Mott–Schottky plots of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C at 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz. (d) Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, (e) PL spectra and (f) transient photocurrent spectra of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, Nb2O5/Nb2C and TT-Nb2O5.

Photocatalytic NO removal efficiencies of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, Nb2O5/Nb2C and TT-Nb2O5 under RH of (a) 25%, (b) 50%, (c) 75% and (d) 100%. The stability of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C in five cycles under RH of (e) 50% and (f) 75%. The light was turned on after reaching adsorption-desorption equilibrium for 5 min in the dark.
(a) NO2 generation amounts over Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C. (b) FTIR spectra of NO conversion processes under visible light over Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C (every five minutes).

(a) Free radical scavenging test of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C under RH = 50%. (b) ESR spectra of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C for •O2 − in dark and under visible-light. (c) Schematic illustrations for the Nb2O5 (001) facet with and without oxygen vacancy. (d) Bond distances for O2 and NO absorbed on (001) facets of Ov-Nb2O5 and Nb2O5.
Mechanisms for separation and transfer of photogenerated charges in visible-light photocatalytic NO removal processes over Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C.

head.ce:title: Oxygen vacancies in actiniae-like Nb2O5/Nb2C MXene heterojunction boosting visible light photocatalytic NO removal

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Photocatalytic oxidation is a green and energy-saving technology for removing the low concentration NO in ambient atmosphere. High efficient and stable photocatalysts are essential for achieving excellent NO conversion effect. In this work, oxygen vacancy-rich Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction photocatalysts were prepared from Nb2C MXene by hydrothermal process and heat treatment in H2/Ar. The (001) facet-dominant Nb2O5 nanorods in-situ grown on Nb2C MXene formed an actiniae-like structure, which promotes the active site exposure and enlarges the reaction interface. Under visible light, the optimized photocatalyst exhibits excellent NO removal rates in the relative humidity range of 25–75%. Mechanism research shows that the oxygen vacancies greatly improve the photocatalytic NO oxidation capacity. Oxygen vacancies on (001) facet of Nb2O5 nanorods can boost the visible light absorption, effectively adsorb and activate the reactant gas. The separation of photogenerated carriers was synergistically enhanced by the oxygen vacancies and Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction.

ce:section.ce:para: Nitric oxide (NO) is an important gaseous pollutant, which causes serious damage to human health and the ecological environment [1]. The research of NO conversion techniques has attracted extensive attention [2–4]. Due to the process can be powered by abundant solar energy, photocatalysis is an important and promising technology to purify the parts-per-billion (ppb) level NO in the ambient atmosphere [5–7]. The photocatalytic NO removal effect depends heavily on the properties of photocatalysts. Many semiconductor materials have been employed as photocatalysts, such as TiO2 [8,9], g-C3N4 [10,11] and Bi-based perovskites [12–14]. Niobium pentoxide (Nb2O5) with good thermal and chemical stability, nontoxicity and unique Lewis acid sites, has been widely used for photocatalytic degradation of water pollutants [15,16]. However, due to the small specific surface area, low utilization of visible-light and rapid recombination of photogenerated carriers [17], so far few works have been carried out towards Nb2O5-based catalysts for visible-light photocatalytic NO removal.

Many strategies have been developed to improve the photocatalytic properties of semiconductor materials. Morphology control is an effective way to enlarge the specific surface area and increase the active sites [18,19]. Compared with the traditional Nb2O5 spheres, the nanorod-structured pseudo-hexagonal TT-Nb2O5 has enlarged specific surface area and improved visible light response [20]. Another effective approach to improve the NO conversion effect of photocatalysts is surface modification [21–23]. The defects in g-C3N4 can act as electron capture centers to reduced charge recombination and accelerate the conversion of NO to the final product [24,25]. The oxygen vacancies on TiO2 could change the band gap width, facilitate the O2 activation and inhibit the photocatalytic NO oxidation towards noxious NO2 [26].

Constructing heterojunction has been proved to be an effective approach to promote the photogenerated carriers separation [27–29]. In recent years, the highly conductive two-dimensional MXene materials are utilized to assemble Schottky junction with semiconductors [30–32]. More interestingly, the MXene materials can be partially in situ oxidized to form metallic oxide/MXene heterojunction [33]. The close integration between metallic oxide and MXene could greatly boost the transfer and separation of photogenerated carriers, which contributes to enhance the photocatalytic performance. Nb2C is a common MXene species, which can be in situ oxidized to form Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction [16,34]. However, the application of Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction in photocatalytic NO removal has not been explored.

In this work, combining the strategies of morphology control, surface modification and heterojunction, oxygen vacancy-rich Nb2O5 nanorods/Nb2C visible-light photocatalysts were prepared from Nb2C MXene by hydrothermal method and heat treatment in H2/Ar. The (001) facet-dominant Nb2O5 nanorods were in-situ grown on Nb2C MXene, forming an actiniae-like structure, which is beneficial for promoting the specific surface area and enlarging the reaction interface with reactant gas. The promotion mechanism of oxygen vacancies on the Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction was systematically investigated by experiments and DFT calculations. Oxygen vacancies on the tentacle-like Nb2O5 nanorods could enhance the visible light absorption, effectively activate the reactants and produce more radical. The separation of photogenerated electrons and holes could be enhanced by the synergistic effect of oxygen vacancies and heterojunction structure. The design and mechanism analysis of this work could provide guidance for the synthesis of high-performance Nb2O5-based catalysts in photocatalytic NO removal.

Nb2C MXene was obtained by the same method as our previous work [35]. Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C was prepared by a hydrothermal reaction followed by heat treatment in H2/Ar atmosphere, as shown in Fig. 1. Typically, 0.2 g Nb2C MXene was added in 40 mL deionized water (DI) and ultrasonic treated for 30 min. The solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated to 180 °C in an oven and kept for 12 h. After cooling down to room temperature naturally, the product was washed several times with DI. The sample was collected by centrifugation, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight. The product was further treated in H2/Ar (8 vol% H2) at 500 °C for 1 h, and denoted as Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. For comparison, the hydrothermal product was also treated in Ar at 500 °C for 1 h, and marked as Nb2O5/Nb2C.

The (001) facet-dominant pseudo-hexagonal Nb2O5 (TT-Nb2O5) was prepared according to the literature [20]. 1.933 g ammonium niobate oxalate hydrate was mixed with 3.6 g oleic acid and 21.6 g trioctylamine, the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave, heated to 180 °C and kept for 6 h. The sample was collected and washed with DI, and treated in air at 500 °C for 1 h.

Phase composition of the photocatalysts was analyzed by a Bruker D8 Discover X-Ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy. Oxygen vacancy and radical signals were tested by a Bruker EMX plus electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer. A JEOL JSM-7001F scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to characterize the morphology and element distribution. Microstructures of the samples were studied by a FEI Tecnai F20 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Specific surface areas of the samples were tested by a Micromeritics ASAP 2460. A ESCALAB 250 Xi X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the element information and valence state. Optical absorption spectra were record by a Shimadzu UV2450 UV–visible diffuse reflection spectrophotometry (DRS), in which BaSO4 was used as the reference. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured with an Edinburgh FLS1000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area was characterized by a Micrometrics ASAP2460. Elemental analysis was performed on an Elementar vario EL cube Analyzer. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was measured by a Shimadzu ICPE-9000 instrument.

Photocatalytic NO removal performances of the photocatalysts were tested with a flow reactor, which was designed and manufactured according to ISO 22197-1:2016 standard. The photocatalysts were washed several times with MQ water (high purity water, Milli-Q water system, UK) to remove the possible impurity. The catalysts were evenly coated on a 100 mm × 49 mm glass plate, which was then put into the flow reactor. The reactor was placed under a 300 W commercial long arc xenon lamp equipped with a 400 nm cut off filter, and the simulated solar light source was shone on the photocatalyst through the quartz window of reactor. NO-containing reaction gas was obtained by mixing 100 ppm NO (N2 as equilibrium gas), dry and wet air. The NO concentration in reaction gas was set as 500 ppb, and the gas flow rate was stabled at 1.2 L min−1. To simulate the real reaction condition in ambient atmosphere, the photocatalysts were tested under the feed gas with relative humidity (RH) = 25%, 50%, 75% and 100%. A Thermo 42i NO-NO-NOx analyzer was used to measure the NO and NO2 concentration in the outlet gas. The reactor was kept in the dark to reach NO adsorption equilibrium for at least 5 min, and then the long arc xenon lamp was turned on. The NO conversion rate was calculated by (1 − C/C0) × 100%, in which C0 and C represent the initial and real-time NO concentration in outlet gas. The NO photocatalytic conversion products remaining on the surface of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C were analyzed by ion chromatograph. The catalyst was washed down from the glass plate with 50 mL MQ water. After ultrasonic treatment for 10 min, the solution was filtered through PTFE membrane (0.22 µm) and then tested by a ThermoFisher Scientific ICS-5000+ ion chromatograph.

Electrochemical properties of the photocatalysts were characterized in a three-electrode system equipped with a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation. 0.1 mol L−1 Na2SO4 aqueous solution was used as electrolyte. The working electrode was prepared by coating photocatalyst on FTO glass, and 10 mm × 10 mm Pt sheet was used as counter electrode, a KCl-saturated Ag/AgCl electrode was employed as the reference electrode.

The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed for the analyzing the interactions between photocatalysts and reactant gases. A plane wave cutoff of 400 eV was employed, the k-points was sampled with the 2 × 2 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack grid. The threshold for the energy convergence was set as 1 × 10−5 eV. A 3 × 3 × 2 supercell of TT-Nb2O5 was first relaxed, and subsequently O was removed from the (001) facet.

ce:section.ce:section-title: FTIR investigation of the photocatalytic reaction
ce:section.ce:para: To reveal the reaction mechanism of NO photocatalytic conversion, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis was performed to monitor the photocatalytic process. Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C was washed with MQ water and then dried at 105 °C for 2 h to remove adsorbed impurities. The feed gas was 50 ppm NO, and the flow rate was kept at 100 mL min−1. The data were collected by a Bruker LUMOS FTIR Microscope every five minutes. Scanning range was 4000–600 cm−1, and the section of 1450–600 cm−1 was analyzed to study the reaction process.

In the low magnification SEM image ( Fig. 2a), it can be seen that Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C possesses a similar structure with Nb2C (Fig. S1). As displayed in the high magnification SEM image of Fig. 2b, dense nanorods are vertically grown on the surface of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, forming an actiniae-like structure. The Nb, C and O are uniformly distributed in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C (Fig. S2), demonstrating the tentacle-like structure is Nb2O5. In the TEM image of Fig. 2c, Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C has layered structure, which is resulting from the two-dimensional Nb2C MXene. As shown in Fig. S3a and b, the Nb2O5 nanorods with a width of about 20 nm are uniformly grown on Nb2C nanosheet. After a 15 min ultrasonic treatment at 250 W, the structure and morphology of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C were still maintained (Fig. S4). The strong interaction between Nb2O5 nanorods and Nb2C was resulting from the in-situ oxidation of hydrothermal process. In the HRTEM of Fig. 2d, a characteristic spacing of 0.393 nm was recognized in the nanorods, which matches well with the (001) lattice plane of TT-Nb2O5. This characteristic spacing can be easily observed in the nanorods, indicating the (001) lattice plane is highly exposed in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C.

Crystal structures of the samples were studied by XRD. As shown in Fig. 2e, the peak at 6.2° in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C refers to the (002) facet crystal plane of Nb2C MXene [36], and the peaks at 22.6°, 28.6° and 46.2° correspond to the (001), (100) and (002) planes of TT-Nb2O5 (JCPDS NO. 28-0317). It is worth noting that the (001) peak is much higher than other peaks, demonstrating that the active (001) facet is dominated in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C [20,37]. This is consistent with the HRTEM results. EPR was employed to validate the existence of oxygen vacancy. As displayed in Fig. 2f, an evident EPR signal can be detected at g = 2.004 in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, which can be ascribed to the electrons trapped by oxygen vacancies [38,39]. This signal is not observed in Nb2O5/Nb2C, suggesting the oxygen vacancies were created by heat treatment in H2/Ar.

The mass ratio of Nb2O5 to Nb2C in photocatalyst was speculated by the content of O and C. Elemental analysis shows that Nb2O5/Nb2C contains O of 20.22 wt% and C of 1.96 wt%, the contents of Nb2O5 and Nb2C are calculated to be 67.19 and 32.29 wt%. Based on the above, the Nb content is calculated to be 77.29 wt%, which is very close with the ICP-OES result of 73.68 wt%. Thus, the ratio of Nb2O5 to Nb2C is clarified to be 2.08. In the N2 adsorption/desorption test, a distinct hysteresis loop exists in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C (Fig. S5a), suggesting the presence of mesopore structure. BET surface area of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is 56 m2 g−1, which is much larger than 1.5 of m2 g−1 of Nb2C (Fig. S5b) and 3.8 m2 g−1 of TT-Nb2O5 (Fig. S5c). The larger specific surface area of actiniae-like structure contributes to the exposure of the active sites, enhances the contact between reactants and the reaction interface, and also improves the light energy utilization [40].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Surface composition and Nb2O5 crystal face control
ce:section.ce:para: Surface element information and valence states of the photocatalysts were investigated by XPS. As shown in Fig. S6, Nb, O and C were detected in the XPS survey spectrum of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C, demonstrating the presence of Nb2O5 and Nb2C [41]. In the high-resolution Nb 3d spectrum of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C ( Fig. 3a), the peaks at 209.5, 206.7, 203.7 eV correspond to the binding energy of NbONb and NbC. In Nb2C, a peak at 207.9 eV can be detected, which can be ascribed to the NbF [42]. It is clear that NbF is formed during the Nb2C preparation process of chemical etching Nb2AlC [35]. This helps to explain the formation of (001) facet-dominated TT-Nb2O5 nanorods, as F− has been widely adopted as phase inducer in the hydrothermal preparation of TiO2 [43,44]. In the high-resolution C 1s spectra (Fig. 3b), the peaks at 288.6, 286.2, 284.6, 281.3 eV can be assigned to OCO, CH, CC and NbC [45]. The NbC in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C further proves the presence of Nb2C. In O 1s spectra (Fig. 3c), the peaks at 531.5 and 529.9 eV can be recognized, which is related to NbOH and NbONb [16]. The relative proportion of NbOH to NbONb in Nb2C is obviously larger than the other two samples, indicating the transformation of Nb2C to Nb2O5 during the hydrothermal process. XPS analysis shows that the contents of O on the surface of Nb2O5/Nb2C and Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C are 45.09 and 40.21 at%, further confirming the exists of oxygen vacancies. This is consistent with the EPR results in Fig. 2f.

The influence of surface elements on the crystal structure of obtained Nb2O5 was investigated. Alkaline treatment was conducted to replace the surface F of Nb2C MXene with OH [46]. The pristine Nb2C MXene was dispersed in 1 M NaOH aqueous solution at room temperature, and stirred for 2 h. The sample was washed with DI and dried in a vacuum overnight at 80 °C. The treated Nb2C was marked as Nb2COH. As shown in EDS and elemental mapping results ( Fig. 4a and b), the F content in Nb2C is reduced from 35.8 at% to 1.4 at% after defluorination. The content of O increases from 22.1 at% to 41.5 at%, indicating the F is replaced by OH. After the hydrothermal process, Nb2COH derived Nb2O5/Nb2C shows obvious difference in XRD pattern comparing with pristine Nb2C derived sample. The intensity of (101) plane diffraction peak is much higher than (001) plane, and the peak of (110) plane can be clearly observed. This results proves that the Nb2C surface F element plays an important role during the formation of (001) facet-dominant Nb2O5 nanorods.

As shown in Fig. 5a, Nb2O5/Nb2C absorbs small amount of visible light. In particular, Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C shows improved absorption in the visible light region. This phenomenon can be attributed to the introduction of oxygen vacancies in Nb2O5 nanorod of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. The band gap (Eg) of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C can be calculated from the Tauc plots. These plots are generated based on (αhν − Eg)1/2 = A(hν − Eg). In this equation, α represents the absorption coefficient, A is the absorption value, h denotes Planck's constant, ν is the frequency, Eg is the energy band gap and c refers to the speed of light. As can be seen in Fig. 5b, the Eg of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C are calculated to be 2.79 eV and 3.06 eV. Obviously, the oxygen vacancies could significantly decrease the band gap width of Nb2O5/Nb2C photocatalyst. From the Mott–Schottky plots of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C at 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz (Fig. 5c), the flat band potential is measured to be −0.75 V vs. Ag/AgCl (converted to −0.55 V vs. NHE) [47,48]. The positive slope of Mott-Schottky plots indicates that Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is an n-type semiconductor. The conduction band (CB) potential of n-type semiconductor is identical with its flat band potential [49], thus the CB of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is −0.55 V. And the valence band (VB) is calculated to be 2.24 V according to E
CB
= E
VB
−E
g .

To explore the charge transfer resistance, the EIS Nyquist curves (shown in Fig. 5d) were studied. The arc radius in EIS Nyquist plots of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C are much smaller than the (001) facet-dominant TT-Nb2O5, indicating that the combination with Nb2C MXene greatly benefits the transfer of photoinduced carriers in the photocatalyst [50,51]. PL spectrum was tested to investigate the recombination rate of photoinduced electrons and holes. The PL intensity of Nb2O5/Nb2C is significantly lower than (001) facet-dominant TT-Nb2O5 (Fig. 5e), which can be attribute to the combining with Nb2C MXene. The close integration of Nb2O5 with Nb2C is beneficial for the transfer of photogenerated carriers, thus reduce the recombination rates. Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C possesses the lowest PL intensity, which means the best separation effect of photoinduced electrons and holes among these photocatalysts. Photocurrent densities of the photocatalysts are displayed in Fig. 5f, in which the current of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is much larger than Nb2O5/Nb2C and TT-Nb2O5. Previous study has shown that oxygen vacancy can act as electron trap in TiO2, offering additional pathway for electrons transfer [26]. The results in this work suggest that oxygen vacancy possesses a similar effect in Nb2O5. The oxygen vacancies in Nb2O5/Nb2C heterojunction photocatalyst can further promote the transfer of electrons, prolong the life of photogenerated carriers, which is in favor of enhancing photocatalytic activity.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photocatalytic NO removal and oxidation products
ce:section.ce:para: The photocatalytic NO purification reaction was performed in a flow reactor under simulated sunlight source. As shown in Fig. 6a–c, Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C possesses high NO removal rate around 80% at RH = 25%, 50% and 75%. As the RH rose to 100%, the photocatalysts show obvious decrease (Fig. 6d), which can be due to the surface active sites were excessively occupied by H2O molecules. To illustrate the trend and rate of the reaction, the initial 10 min of Fig. 6a–d was shown in Fig. S7. After the light was turned on, Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C possesses the optimal photocatalytic NO conversion activity. The NO conversion rates can reach the maximum in 3 min, demonstrating Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is a highly efficient NO removal photocatalyst. The NO removal rates of Nb2O5/Nb2C and TT-Nb2O5 are inferior to Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. The enhancement in photocatalytic NO removal performance of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C can be attributed to the synergistic effect of heterojunction and oxygen vacancies. To test the photocatalytic performance stability under simulated real atmospheric conditions, Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is further studied by the 5 cycle tests with RH = 50% and 75%. As shown in Fig. 6e and f, Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C still matins high NO removal rates after the 150 min test. The excellent photocatalytic activity and stability are essential for the practical application.

Another important aspect for the photocatalytic NO removal is the formed noxious product NO2 during the reaction. As displayed in Fig. 7a, under RH = 50%, the maximum NO2 production of Nb2O5/Nb2C is 113.5 ppb, and the data is 69.2 ppb in Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. After the 30 min photocatalytic reaction, NO2 production of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is reduced to 18.9 ppb. The NO conversion product remaining on the surface of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C was analyzed by ion chromatograph. As shown in Fig. S8, the peak of NO3 − can be observed, and the concentration is measured to be 12.35 mg L−1. The ion chromatograph result suggests that NO3 − is the main oxidation product in photocatalytic NO conversion.

The photocatalytic process under visible light was also monitored by FTIR. As can be observed in Fig. 7b, the absorption peaks at 1386, 1119 and 1049 cm−1 increased gradually as the reaction progress, which can be attributed to the production and accumulation of NO3 −, monodentate NO3 − and bidentate NO3 −. The FTIR analysis proves NO is oxidized to NO3 −, which is consistent with the ion chromatograph result. The oxygen vacancies of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C enhance the NO removal rate while reduce the NO2 production, thus improve the selectivity of NO to NO3 −.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Active species determination and the role of oxygen vacancies
ce:section.ce:para: Radical scavenger studies were carried out to investigate the active species participated in the photocatalytic NO conversion over Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C at RH = 50%. The scavengers Tert-butanol (TBA), p-benzoquinone (PBQ), potassium iodide (KI), and potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7) were employed to capture hydroxy radicals (•OH), superoxide radicals (•O2 −), holes (h+), and electrons (e−), respectively [52,53]. The results are presented in Fig. 8a, from which can be seen that after the addition of TBA, a slight decrease occurs for the NO removal rate. The trapping of •OH shows very limited impact on photocatalytic activity of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. KI exhibits significant inhibitory effect on the NO removal rate, indicating h+ participates in the photocatalytic NO oxidation process. As can be seen, PBQ and K2Cr2O7 display very significant inhibitory effects, suggesting e− and •O2 − play decisive roles for NO removal. Considering •O2 − is formed by the reaction of e− and O2, the outstanding photocatalytic activity of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is closely related with photogenerated electrons. ESR was carried out to directly detect the reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated by Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C under photoexcitation. The spin traps 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) can combine with •O2 − and •OH to form DMPO-•O2 − in methanol and DMPO-•OH in aqueous [54–56]. Only low-intensity DMPO-•OH signals can be probed in the samples under irradiation (Fig. S9), certifying very few •OH radicals are produced. As shown in the Fig. 8b, no obvious characteristic signal for DMPO-•O2 − can be detected in dark for both Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C and Nb2O5/Nb2C. Under irradiation, the intensity of DMPO-•O2 − typical signal for Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is much higher than Nb2O5/Nb2C, indicating more •O2 − radicals are formed. Undoubtedly, more photogenerated electrons of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C reacted with O2, thus producing more •O2 − radicals. This agrees well with the photocurrent density results in Fig. 5f.

DFT calculation is an effective way to investigate the effect of active sites on free radical generation and reactants activation [57–59]. The structural models of Nb2O5 (001) facet with and without oxygen vacancy were displayed in Fig. 8c. The adsorption energy of O2 over the surface of TT-Nb2O5 (001) facet is calculated to be −1.12 eV. After the introduction of oxygen vacancy, the adsorption energy is changed to −5.90 eV (Fig. S10). Meanwhile, the OO bond length of O2 is elongated to 1.45 Å from 1.24 Å (Fig. 8d). The significant increase in bond length means that OO coulomb interaction is weaken and O2 can be activated more easily. These results indicate that the oxygen vacancies on (001) facet of TT-Nb2O5 is beneficial for the adsorption of O2 and also the activation of O2 to •O2 −. Therefore, higher intensity of DMPO-•O2 − typical signal for Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C can be detected than Nb2O5/Nb2C in ESR test (Fig. 8b). The oxygen vacancies on (001) facet shows similar effect on the other reactant NO. The adsorption energy of NO on the surface Ov-Nb2O5 is −4.52 eV, which is much lower than −0.93 eV of Nb2O5 (Fig. S11). And the NO bond length of NO is enlarged to 1.35 Å from 1.21 Å. The above calculations demonstrate that the introduction of oxygen vacancies on Nb2O5 could further promotes the adsorption and activation of reactant, and also the formation of •O2 − radicals.

Base on the above experimental and DFT calculation results, the photocatalytic NO removal mechanism on Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C can be analyzed. Under visible light irradiation, the TT-Nb2O5 nanorods are excited to form electrons and holes. Photocatalystic NO purification mechanism can be inferred as follows:
Photocatalysts + hν → e− + h+
e− + O2 → •O2 −
h+ + H2O (OH−) → •OH
•O2 − + NO → NO3 −
•OH/h+ + NO → NO2
•OH/h+ + NO → NO3 −

Fig. 9 displays the energy band and photocatalystic NO conversion mechanism of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. TT-Nb2O5 nanorods with abundant oxygen vacancies has improved visible light absorption. Under irradiation, the photogenerated electrons jump from the VB to the CB of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C. The close integration of TT-Nb2O5 nanorods and Nb2C MXene benefits the transfer of photogenerated electrons. Oxygen vacancies can act as electron trap, offering additional pathways for electrons transfer, further restraining the recombination of photogenerated carriers. The CB potential (−0.55 V) of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is more negative than the •O2 − formation potential (−0.33 V), thus the electrons gathered on Nb2C MXene and oxygen vacancies can react with O2 to generate •O2 −, which participates in NO oxidation reaction. Besides, oxygen vacancies can promote the adsorption and activation of reactants, further enhancing the deep oxidation of NO to NO3 −. The VB potential (2.24 V) of Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C is very close to the H2O/•OH redox potential (2.27 V), the •OH radical is difficult to be produced, this explains the weak DMPO-•OH signals in Fig. S9. The H2O molecules in feed gas cannot be effectively transformed to •OH, thus contributed limitedly to the NO conversion reaction. Benefited from the abundant •O2 −, the large reaction interface and oxygen vacancies, Ov-Nb2O5/Nb2C possesses excellent NO removal properties in the RH range of 25–75%.

In summary, oxygen vacancy-rich Nb2O5 nanorods/Nb2C visible-light photocatalysts were prepared from Nb2C MXene by hydrothermal method and heat treatment in H2/Ar. The (001) facet-dominant Nb2O5 nanorods in-situ grown on Nb2C MXene forms an actiniae-like structure, which is beneficial for promoting the specific surface area and enlarging the reaction interface. The optimized photocatalyst exhibits high NO removal rate and low noxious NO2 production. The experimental and DFT calculation results demonstrate that oxygen vacancies on (001) facet of Nb2O5 nanorods are beneficial for enhancing visible light absorption, adsorption and activation for reactant gas, and formation of •O2 − radicals. Oxygen vacancies and Schottky heterojunction synergy enhance the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes. The present work provides a new route for the design of high-performance Nb2O5-based photocatalysts in air purification.
